summary: A syllabus-led, method-focused Maths paper: mostly short-answer and procedural, with clear expectations to show working and no calculator. The difficulty is driven by accuracy (decimals, negatives, fractions) and a small number of classic reasoning items rather than novel puzzle formats.

topicWeighting.topic: negative numbers and order of operations
fractions (compare, add, multiply; fraction of a whole; simplify)
algebra (solve linear equations; form and solve from a word problem)
geometry and measurement (perimeter with square tiling; area/width from area)

formatRules: No calculator. Require working to be shown for all non-trivial questions; design multi-step questions with partial-credit milestones.
Overall style is short-answer and procedural, with multi-part questions labelled a), b), c) grouped into a small number of stems (arithmetic set, negatives/BIDMAS set, fractions set, algebra set).
Arithmetic warm-up should include integer plus/minus, multi-digit multiplication and division, and at least one multi-step decimal expression that tests place value alignment.
Include a short negative-number mini-set (subtracting a negative, multiplying or dividing a negative) plus one explicit order-of-operations item with brackets.

Fractions should include: (i) comparison of two proper fractions, (ii) addition with unlike denominators, (iii) a product of several fractions designed to simplify/cancel, and (iv) a fraction-of-a-whole context question where the remainder fraction is required.
Percentages should appear as direct 'find x% of y' questions, usually producing whole-number outputs without a calculator.
Number properties should include short prompts like listing first five multiples and listing all factors of a small integer.
Algebra should include simple one-step and two-step equations and one word problem translating statements like 'twice as many' and '12 more' into a linear equation.
Geometry should include a perimeter question where a rectangle is subdivided into equal squares and a single given length forces inference of side lengths.
Measurement/area should include a stepped-rectangle or composite diagram where areas of rectangles are given and one width/length must be deduced using area = length times width.
Include one classic counting question about the number of squares on an n by n board (explicitly hint that it is more than n squared).
Keep wording direct and low-fluff; difficulty should come from accuracy and multi-step method rather than novel rule systems.

UNKNOWN: official time limit and total marks were not clearly inferable from the provided sample; default to a 45-minute online mock and calibrate so most candidates reach the final counting question with some time pressure.
maths.difficultyNotes: Easier-to-moderate compared to puzzle-heavy 11+ Maths. It mainly tests reliable core skills and clean methods; the main stretch comes from careful multi-step arithmetic and a classic non-routine counting problem near the end.

formatRules: UNKNOWN: no English paper text was provided for this school; do not infer passage style, question stems, or writing tasks until English papers are supplied.
english.difficultyNotes: UNKNOWN: English difficulty cannot be inferred without English papers.

commonWrongAnswers: Place-value errors in multi-step decimal expressions and long multiplication/division.
Sign mistakes with negatives (especially subtracting a negative) and ignoring brackets in order-of-operations questions.
Fraction errors: comparing by numerator/denominator only, incorrect common denominators, not simplifying, or not cancelling in products.
Percentage misconceptions (treating 30% as 30; wrong conversion to a fraction/decimal).
Confusing factors with multiples; forgetting that factors include 1 and the number itself.
Algebra translation mistakes: misreading 'twice as many' or '12 more' when forming equations.
Perimeter-from-squares mistakes: not using the equal-square constraint to infer lengths or double-counting internal edges.
Counting-squares question answered as only n squared (counting 1 by 1 squares only) and missing larger squares.
markingAndFeedback.explanationTone: Clear, calm, and concrete: show the standard method in a few steps, point out the single most likely trap (sign, place value, simplifying), and finish with a quick check (estimate, substitute back, or simplify check).

generatorHints: Do NOT copy any original questions.
Match the flavour, not the exact content.
Avoid references to printing or PDFs.
Keep questions suitable for an online timed exam.
Prioritise direct, curriculum-style short-answer questions with required working and minimal puzzle narrative.
Use multi-part stems to mirror the paper structure (arithmetic set, negatives/BIDMAS set, fractions set, algebra set).
Include at least one perimeter-from-squares diagram task and one stepped-area missing-length diagram task.
Include exactly one classic 'count the squares on an n by n grid' style question near the end as a stretch item.
